introduction.p: These exercises address measurement of angles, particularly in radians, and use of the relationship \boxed{\theta = \frac{s}{r}}. In this equation, \theta is the radian measure of the angle and s is the length of the arc subtended by the angle in a circle of radius r.

statement.p: Accurately sketch the angles \theta = \frac{11\pi}{6} and \theta = - \frac{8\pi}{3} without converting to degrees.

solution.p:
For \theta = 11\pi/6, equally divide 1 revolution into 12 parts. Each is \pi/6 = 30^\circ. Count off 11 of them in the counterclockwise orientation.
For \theta = -8\pi/3, equally divide 1 revolution into 6 parts. Each is \pi/3 = 60^\circ. Count off 8 of them in the clockwise orientation.

statement.p: How many degrees is an angle of 1 radian? How many radians is an angle of 1 degree? What's bigger: one degree or one radian?

solution.p: Recall 180^\circ = \pi radians. So, dividing by \pi, 1 \, {\rm radian} = \frac{180^\circ }{\pi} \approx 57^\circ So one radian is much bigger than 1 degree! Similarly, 1^{\circ} = \frac{\pi}{180} \approx 0.017

statement.p: True or False: The symbol \pi must be used whenever we measure an angle with units of radians.

solution.p: False! Often times we see nice angles which are rational mutliples of \pi when expressed in radians. But \pi is just a number \pi \approx 3.14 and is not conveying units at all. In fact, angles are dimensionless quantities and have no units.

statement.p: A wheel with radius 16 inches rolls without slipping along the ground turning to form an angle of 495^\circ. How far does the center of the wheel move, in feet?

hint.p: You must first convert the angle to radians.

solution.p:
The distance travelled is exactly the amount of the outer arclength of the wheel that touches along the ground. This is related to the angle by s = r \theta, provided \theta is measured in radians. So,
s = r \theta = {16\, \rm inches} \times 495^\circ \times \frac{\pi}{180^\circ} \approx 138 \, {\rm inches}

statement.p: A vinyl record plays at 33 rpm (revolutions per minute). If the diameter of the record is 10 inches, how fast is a speck of dust on the outer edge of the record moving in inches per minute? How far will it move in inches after a song of 4 minutes and 10 seconds?

hint.p: First find the angular velocity in radians per minute!

answer.p: The speck of dust will move at about 1036.5 inches per minute. After 4 minutes and 10 seconds, this will go about 4318 inches.

p.em: These exercises address the trigonometry of right triangles and the fundamental definitions of sine, cosine, and tangent of an angle \theta as ratio of sides of a right triangle.

statement.p: Find the sine, cosine, and tangent of the angles \alpha and \beta in the triangle below.

solution.p:
The missing side x satisfies:
4^2+x^2 =10^2 \Rightarrow x^2 = 100-16 = 86 \Rightarrow x = \sqrt{86}
Thus, \sin \alpha = \frac{\sqrt{86}}{10}, \cos \alpha = \frac{2}{5}, and \tan \alpha = \frac{\sqrt{86}}{4}.
Now for the other angle, \cos \beta = \frac{\sqrt{86}}{10}, \sin \beta = \frac{2}{5}, and \tan \beta = \frac{4}{\sqrt{86}} = \frac{2 \sqrt{86}}{43}.

statement.p: Given that \sin(\theta) = 1/5 and that the hypotenuse is 7 inches, find the length of the remaining sides of the right triangle containing \theta.

answer.p: The side opposite \theta has length \frac{7}{5} while the side adjacent has length \frac{14\sqrt{6}}{5}.

statement.p: Standing at a point 100 feet from the base of a building, you measure the angle of elevation from the ground to the top of the building to be 40^\circ. A cellphone tower is mounted onto the top of the building. From the same point you measure the angle of elevation from the ground to the top of the cell tower to be 50^\circ. How tall is the building? How tall is the cellphone tower? Use a calculator.

solution.p:
The height h of the building satisfies
\tan 40^\circ = \frac{h}{100 \, \rm feet} \Rightarrow h = \tan 40^\circ \times 100 \, \rm feet
With a calculator in degree mode, I estimate that h \approx 84 \, \rm feet. The combined height H of the building and cell tower satisfies
\tan 50^\circ = \frac{H}{100 \, \rm feet} \Rightarrow H = \tan 50^\circ \times 100 \, \rm feet \Rightarrow H \approx 119 \, \rm feet
The tower itself is 119 - 84 = 35 feet.

p.em: These exercises review the special triangles 45-45-90 and 30-69-90 that allow us to determine the exact values of trigonometric functions for these commonly used angles.
The video reviews some of the topics above.

statement.p: Practice drawing the two special triangles that allow you to determine the exact values of the trigonometric functions of \pi/4, \pi/3, and \pi/6.

Two acute angles \alpha and \beta are called complementary angles if \alpha+\beta = \pi/2. How are the trigonometric function values of complementary angles related? Illustrate your conclusion with the 30-60-90 degree special triangle.

solution.p:
The sine of a complementary angle is the cosine of the original:
\cos \alpha = \sin (\pi/2 - \alpha) = \sin \beta
Similarly, the cosine of the complementary angle is the sine of the original:
\sin \alpha = \cos (\pi/2 - \alpha) = \cos \beta
Compare \alpha = \pi/3 and \beta = \pi/6 in the special triangle. For instance,
\sin (\pi/3) = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} = \cos(\pi/6)
